head.title: A Big Buckeye Is Eclipsed by the Gators' Guards

hedline.hl1: A Big Buckeye Is Eclipsed by the Gators' Guards
hedline.hl2: The Gators’ Guards Eclipse the Buckeyes’ Big Man

block.p: The ball rolled loose in the open floor, and a Florida guard was there to snatch it. Each time there was a quick pass to an open Gators shooter, a 3-point shot seemed to fall through the net.
That is how it went for Florida on Monday night when it won its second consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament title with an 84-75 victory against Ohio State.
Gators guards Taurean Green and Lee Humphrey and the wing player Corey Brewer combined for 43 points.
The ball rolled loose in the open floor, and a Florida guard was there to snatch it. Each time there was a quick pass to an open Gators shooter, a 3-point shot seemed to fall through the net.
That is how it went for Florida on Monday night when it won its second consecutive N.C.A.A. tournament title with an 84-75 victory against Ohio State.
Florida won with the pretty play -- the 3-pointer -- and it won with the hustle play -- diving after loose balls.

''We definitely came up with almost all the loose balls tonight; that was the key to the game,'' point guard Taurean Green said. ''When they shot a 3 and we knew they were going to be long rebounds, we did a good job blocking out and chasing after long rebounds.''
Florida outrebounded Ohio State, 38-28. Corey Brewer had eight of those rebounds. The Buckeyes would shoot a 3-pointer and miss, and the ball would fly back out where the Gators would control it.
''That's the reason they beat us,'' Ohio State guard Jamar Butler said. ''They got every hustle play.''
Buckeyes forward Ivan Harris, referring to his teammate Greg Oden, said, ''Greg is blocking shots, loose balls are rolling around, and they are picking them up and shooting 3s.''
Florida's perimeter players -- Green, Brewer and Lee Humphrey -- took all 18 of the team's 3-pointers and made 10.
It was a barrage of 3-pointers that broke open a 2-point game in the first half. In a 92-second stretch, Humphrey hit a 3, Brewer hit a 3, and Green hit a 3 to give the Gators a 33-22 lead.
Ohio State made only 4 of 23 of 3-point attempts. Guards Ron Lewis, Mike Conley Jr. and Butler made only 2 of 13 3-pointers.

Ohio State had a difficult time making 3s because Florida's defense was based outside-in. The Gators guarded the 3-point line and decided to play one-on-one in the post against Oden, the freshman star center.
Oden scored 25 points, but his 2-pointers did not match up to Florida's 3-pointers.

''We felt like we could play straight up in the post; 2s can't really beat you if you can guard the 3-point line,'' Brewer said. ''We let it go inside, played behind and made him try and get his. Defensively, we did good; we had each other's backs all night.''
Ohio State has been able to manage its opponents' offense in this tournament with the help of a 2-3 zone defense, but the Buckeyes would not go into the zone against Florida's sharpshooters.
''Zone or man-to-man, it wouldn't have made any difference,'' Harris said. ''They were just making shots.''
Ohio State did not make shots, which is not surprising against Florida. Coming into the Final Four, opponents had shot only 29 percent from the 3-point line against the Gators.
The Buckeyes were the latest team to be frustrated by the energetic play on the perimeter of the Florida guards.
''Coach told us to keep shooting,'' Butler said. ''They just weren't falling.''
